Thomas L Roche wrote: 

> > 3) Implement (2) and check the fix (1).
> > I've chosen this because my current fault *didn't* have any test
> > code for (2) and when added - I only got a green bar!? So closer
> > inspection of (1) I noted that I was actually wrapping a number of
> > DocumentListeners to get the effect I desired - unfortunately I was
> > add them in the wrong order. 
> 
> You might consider
> 4) expose API to getEffectDesired() and then testGettingEffectDesired

I'm probably being thick, but I am not sure what you're getting at here,
could you expand please?  

My confusion comes (I think) from the fact that I am trying to make my UI
"lightweight" in terms of functionality embedded within it.  So from that
viewpoint the effect I am interested in is that my edit control behaves
correctly.  So the UI code becomes responsible for instantiating and using
this text contol.  Perhaps a better (more TDD friendly?) approach would be
to realise that I needed a text control to be have in a certain manner and
extract that from my UI and drive that?  Having said that I'd still probably
have nested the construction of the DocumentListeners, so I'd still end up
with the same quandry (albeit on a smaller scale).

> > So whilst (1) on its own would have worked, I like (2) as well
> > because the listener can be used in a number of different ways and
> > (1) only tests a specific usage.

> Another thing to consider: which is more stable, your UI or your
> backend? If the latter, esp if you expect to expose it more ways in
> future (e.g. as a service), you should definitely put more test effort
> into it--over time you will "spread the overhead." But if your UI is
> more stable, and you expect to "forklift-replace" the current backend,
> then I might not bother.

History has shown that, in this context, the backend is/will be more stable
(which is another reason why I adopted the two pronged approach).
